United Nations.passage: United Nations (UN) is an intergovernmental organization founded on 26 June 1945. It was founded to promote international cooperation and maintain international peace and security. The organization operates through various bodies, including the General Assembly, the Security Council, the International Court of Justice, and the Secretariat. The UN's primary purpose is to prevent conflicts between nations and to promote sustainable development by promoting international cooperation on issues such as climate change, poverty reduction, and the promotion of human rights. The organization has 193 member states, making it the largest international organization in the world. The UN's headquarters is located in New York City, with additional offices in Geneva, Vienna, and Nairobi.

World Health Organization.passage: World Health Organization (WHO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations (UN) that is responsible for international health governance and global health cooperation. The organization was established on 7 April 1948, with its headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland. WHO is the only specialized agency of the UN that has a constitution, which defines its function and purpose. The WHO's primary role is to direct and coordinate international health within the United Nations system. The organization seeks to promote health and well-being by providing leadership and technical expertise on a range of global health issues. The WHO's 193 member states work together to achieve its goals, which include promoting healthy lifestyles, preventing disease outbreaks, and ensuring access to high-quality health care. The WHO's work is guided by the World Health Assembly, which is the governing body of the organization. The assembly meets annually and is attended by representatives from all WHO member states. The WHO also works closely with other UN agencies, such as the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), as well as with other international organizations, such as the World Bank and the World Food Programme. The WHO's activities are funded through a combination of member state contributions, voluntary contributions from governments and other organizations, and earnings from its own investments. The organization's budget for 2020–2021 was approximately $4.8 billion. Through its work, the WHO aims to promote health and well-being for all people, regardless of their nationality, ethnicity, or economic status.

qae_pairs.explanation: The World Health Organization (WHO) was established on 7 April 1948.

qae_pairs.explanation: The governing body of the World Health Organization that guides its work and meets annually is the World Health Assembly. The World Health Assembly is the decision-making body of the WHO and is attended by representatives from all WHO member states. It sets the overall policies and directions for the organization and approves the WHO's budget. The assembly also reviews and endorses the work of the WHO's executive board and the director-general's reports.

International Monetary Fund.passage: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is a specialized agency of the United Nations that was established to promote international monetary cooperation, facilitate international trade, foster economic growth, and reduce poverty around the world. The IMF provides financial assistance, monitors economic developments, and offers policy advice to its member countries. The IMF was created in 1944 at a United Nations conference in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, with the aim of promoting international economic cooperation and stabilizing exchange rates. The organization's headquarters are located in Washington, D.C., and it has 190 member countries. The IMF's primary purpose is to ensure the stability of the international monetary system—the system of exchange rates and international payments that enables countries to transact with each other. The organization provides financial assistance to member countries experiencing balance of payments difficulties or other economic problems, and it works with member countries to develop policies that promote sustainable economic growth and reduce poverty. In addition to providing financial assistance, the IMF also conducts economic research and analysis, and provides policy advice to member countries. The organization publishes a range of reports and data on the global economy, including the World Economic Outlook, which provides forecasts for the global economy and individual countries. The IMF is governed by a board of governors, which is comprised of representatives from each member country. The board of governors makes decisions about the organization's policies and operations, and it also appoints the executive board, which is responsible for carrying out the day-to-day work of the IMF.

World Bank.passage: World Bank The World Bank is a financial institution that provides loans, policy advice, and technical assistance to countries in order to reduce poverty and promote sustainable development. The bank's formal name is the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), and it is part of the World Bank Group, which also includes the International Development Association (IDA) and the International Finance Corporation (IFC). The World Bank was founded in 1944 at the Bretton Woods Conference in New Hampshire, United States, along with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The bank's primary purpose is to provide financing for projects that promote economic development and reduce poverty in developing countries. The bank's headquarters are located in Washington, D.C., and it has regional offices in various countries around the world. The World Bank provides a range of financial products and services to its client countries, including loans, grants, and technical assistance. Its lending is focused on areas such as agriculture, education, energy, health, infrastructure, and social development. The bank also provides policy advice and capacity building to help countries develop their economies and reduce poverty. The World Bank has been criticized for its lending policies and the impact they have on developing countries. Some critics argue that the bank's lending practices perpetuate a cycle of debt and dependency, while others argue that the bank's policies are too focused on promoting private sector development and not enough on addressing social needs. Despite these criticisms, the World Bank remains an important player in the global development community, and its lending and policy advice continue to have a significant impact on the economies of developing countries around the world.

qae_pairs.question: What is the formal name of the World Bank?
qae_pairs.answer: the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
qae_pairs.explanation: The formal name of the World Bank is the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD).

European Union.passage: The European Union (EU) is a political and economic union of 27 member states located primarily in Europe. It was established with the signing of the Maastricht Treaty on 7 February 1992, which entered into force on 1 November 1993. The EU has its headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, and its institutions include the European Parliament, the European Council, the European Commission, and the Court of Justice of the European Union. The EU was founded with the aim of creating a single market where people, goods, services, and capital could move freely across borders. Today, the EU is the largest single market in the world, with a population of over 500 million people and a combined gross domestic product (GDP) of over $20 trillion. The EU has also expanded its role in recent years to include areas such as foreign policy, justice and home affairs, and defense. The EU operates on the principle of supranationalism, which means that decisions are made at the EU level rather than at the level of individual member states. This is achieved through a system of shared sovereignty, where member states agree to pool some of their powers together in order to achieve common goals. The EU has also established a single currency, the euro, which is used by 19 of its 27 member states. The EU is governed by a number of institutions, including the European Parliament, the European Council, the European Commission, and the Court of Justice of the European Union. The European Parliament is made up of 705 members who are elected every five years by the citizens of the EU. The European Council is made up of the heads of state or government of the EU member states, who meet regularly to discuss issues of common interest.

African Union.passage: The African Union (AU) is a continental union consisting of 55 member states in Africa. The AU was established on 26 March 2002 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and it replaced the Organisation of African Unity (OAU). The AU aims to promote and enhance unity, solidarity, cohesion, and cooperation among African countries and to promote African integration and development. The AU is headquartered in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and is governed by the Assembly of the African Union, which is made up of the heads of state and government of its member states. The AU has a number of bodies and institutions, including the Pan-African Parliament, the African Court of Justice and Human Rights, and the African Central Bank. The AU has also established a number of initiatives and programs aimed at promoting peace, security, and development in Africa, including the African Peace and Security Architecture and the Agenda 2063: The Africa We Want.

Association of Southeast Asian Nations.passage: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a political and economic organization in Southeast Asia. The organization has 10 member states: Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam. North Atlantic Treaty Organization.passage: North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is a political and military alliance of 30 North American and European countries. NATO was established on 4 April 1949, in the aftermath of World War II, with the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington, D.C. Its primary purpose is to provide collective defense against potential security threats from outside the alliance, while also promoting democratic values, stability, and cooperation among its member states. NATO's headquarters are located in Brussels, Belgium, and the organization is led by the Secretary General, currently Jens Stoltenberg. The member countries of NATO are: Albania, Belgium, Bulgaria, Canada, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Montenegro, the Netherlands, North Macedonia, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the United States. NATO's key functions include political and military consultation, coordination, and decision-making among member states. The organization also engages in crisis management, conflict prevention, and peacekeeping operations around the world. NATO's military capabilities include land, air, and sea forces, as well as nuclear deterrence. NATO has played a significant role in shaping international security and promoting peace and stability in Europe and beyond. The organization has been involved in a range of military operations, including the Korean War, the Gulf War, the war in Afghanistan, and the fight against terrorism.

Organization of American States.passage: The Organization of American States (OAS), or simply the Americas, is a regional intergovernmental organization founded on 1948 in Bogotá, Colombia. The organization has 35 member states in North, Central, and South America and the Caribbean. The OAS is the oldest regional organization in the world and is responsible for promoting democracy, human rights, and social and economic development in the Americas. The OAS operates through its General Secretariat, which is headquartered in Washington, D.C., United States, and its member states appoint a Secretary General to lead the organization. It holds regular meetings of foreign ministers and heads of state, as well as specialized meetings on specific issues. The organization also has a system of diplomatic representation, with permanent missions to the United Nations and other international organizations. Despite its successes, the OAS has faced criticism for its perceived ineffectiveness in addressing some regional issues, such as the ongoing crisis in Venezuela. Shanghai Cooperation Organization.passage: Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) is a political, economic, and security alliance of eight member states in Asia and Europe. The organization was founded on June 15, 2001, in Shanghai, China, by the leaders of China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. Its charter was adopted on June 15, 2002, and it was renamed as the Shanghai Cooperation Organization Charter. The organization's main objectives are to strengthen mutual trust and good-neighborly relations among member states, to promote their effective cooperation in the areas of economy, trade, investment, technology, culture, education, energy, transportation, and environmental protection, to maintain regional peace, stability, and security, to promote the development of the region's economy and social progress, and to enhance the well-being of the people of the region. The SCO has a unique character as a regional organization, which is based on the principles of mutual respect, equality, mutual benefit, and consultation and cooperation. It is open to other countries that share its goals and values, and that are willing to work together to achieve them. the World Health Assembly.passage: The World Health Assembly (WHA) is the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO). It is attended by delegations from all WHO Member States and meets annually in Geneva, Switzerland. The WHA sets the policies and budgets of the WHO, and makes recommendations to Member States on global health issues. It also serves as a forum for discussions on specific health issues and for the adoption of resolutions and decisions. the European Parliament.passage: European Parliament The European Parliament is the legislative branch of the European Union (EU). The Parliament has 12 different committees that deal with specific areas of policy, such as economic and monetary affairs, foreign affairs, and internal affairs. It also has a President and 14 Vice-Presidents who are elected by the members for two and a half year terms. The President chairs plenary sessions and represents the Parliament in external matters. The treaty also includes provisions for the cooperation and coordination of foreign and security policy among member states. 8. The Maastricht Treaty has been amended several times since its signing, including the Treaty of Amsterdam in 1997, which made further changes to the EU's institutions and policies. 9. The Commission is divided into different departments or directorates-general, each responsible for a specific area of policy. These include agriculture, climate action, competition, digital economy and society, education, employment, energy, environment, health and food safety, internal market, justice and consumers, research and innovation, and trade. the African Court of Justice and Human R.passage: African Court of Justice and Human Rights The African Court of Justice and Human Rights is a continental court based in Arusha, Tanzania. It was established by the African Union (AU) on 17 July 2014, with the aim of promoting and protecting human rights and the rule of law in Africa. The court has the power to interpret and apply the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, as well as other relevant human rights instruments. It also has the power to enforce its decisions, which are binding on the countries that have ratified the charter. The court is composed of 11 judges, who are elected for a term of three years by the AU Assembly. The court's headquarters is located in Arusha, Tanzania, and it has a branch office in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

The country experiences two main seasons: the dry season from November to April and the wet season from May to October. the ASEAN Economic Community.passage: 1. The ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) is a single market and production base that aims to promote economic integration and cooperation among the ten member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). 2. The AEC was established on 31 December 2015, with the goal of creating a more competitive and dynamic region by reducing barriers to trade and investment, promoting greater foreign investment, and facilitating the free flow of goods, services, investment, and skilled labor across national borders. 3. The AEC is designed to be a people-centered community that benefits all members of society, including businesses, workers, and consumers. It aims to create a more inclusive and sustainable economy that is resilient to external shocks and able to compete on a global scale. 4. The AEC is supported by a range of initiatives and programs aimed at strengthening the region's economic integration, including the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA), the ASEAN Investment Area (AIA), and the ASEAN Single Window. 5. The AEC is also working to enhance connectivity and infrastructure in the region, with a focus on improving transportation, telecommunications, and energy networks. This will help to reduce logistics costs, increase trade and investment flows, and improve the overall business environment. 6. Despite some challenges and obstacles, the AEC has made significant progress in its first few years of operation, with ASEAN countries continuing to deepen their economic integration and cooperation. The AEC is seen as a key driver of economic growth and development in the region, and is expected to play an increasingly important role in global trade and investment in the years ahead.

the Inter-American Development Bank.passage: The Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) is a financial institution established in 1959 to promote economic development in the Western Hemisphere. The IDB has a mandate to support the economic development of its member countries by financing development projects and providing technical assistance. The IDB is headquartered in Washington, D.C. and has offices in several Latin American and Caribbean countries. The IDB provides loans, grants, and technical assistance to its member countries to support projects in areas such as infrastructure, education, health, and the environment. The IDB also conducts research and provides policy advice to its member countries. The IDB is owned by its member countries, which are located in North, Central, and South America, as well as the Caribbean. The IDB is governed by a Board of Governors, which is made up of representatives from its member countries. The IDB also has a President, who is appointed by the Board of Governors, and a staff of over 3,000 people. The IDB has provided financing for a wide range of projects, including the construction of roads, bridges, and other infrastructure, as well as projects to improve access to education, healthcare, and clean water. The IDB has also provided funding for renewable energy projects and for efforts to combat climate change. The IDB works closely with other multilateral development banks, such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, to support economic development in the Western Hemisphere. The IDB is committed to promoting sustainable development and reducing poverty in the region.

Colombia.passage: Colombia is a sovereign state largely situated in the northwest of South America, but also comprising territories in Central America. Colombia shares its borders to the northwest with Panama, to the north with the Caribbean Sea, to the east with Venezuela and Brazil, and to the south with Ecuador and Peru. The country's capital and largest city is Bogotá, which is located in the center of the country. Colombia is a unitary constitutional republic comprising 32 departments. The territory of what is now Colombia was originally inhabited by indigenous peoples including the Muisca, Quimbaya, and Tayrona. The Spanish arrived in 1499 and initially founded Santa Marta, which is the first permanent settlement in the Americas. Colombia gained its independence from Spain in 1819, and since then has undergone a variety of political and social processes, including periods of instability and conflict. Today, Colombia is a democratic republic with a presidential system of government. The economy is based largely on the export of agricultural products, particularly coffee, as well as mining and oil. Colombia is known for its rich biodiversity, including tropical rainforests, Andean mountains, and both Caribbean and Pacific coastlines. The country is also home to a diverse range of cultures and languages, including Spanish, English, and indigenous languages.

Bogotá.passage: Bogotá is the capital and largest city of Colombia. It is located in the central part of the country, in the Andes mountains, at an altitude of 2,640 meters (8,660 ft) above sea level. With a population of over 8 million people, Bogotá is the third-largest city in the Americas, behind São Paulo and Mexico City. The city is divided into 20 localities, each with its own mayor and city council. Bogotá is a center for commerce, industry, and culture in Colombia. It is home to many universities, museums, and theaters. The city has a tropical rainforest climate with two distinct seasons: a wet season and a dry season. The wet season usually runs from April to November, while the dry season runs from December to March. Bogotá has a well-preserved historic center, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The city also has many parks and green spaces, including the 3,000-hectare (7,400-acre) Simón Bolívar Park, which is one of the largest urban parks in the world. The city is served by El Dorado International Airport, which is one of the largest airports in Latin America. Bogotá is also a major transportation hub, with a metro system, buses, and taxis providing access to other parts of the country.

OAS.passage: OAS The Organization of American States (OAS) is an inter-governmental organization founded on 30 April 1948, for the purposes of regional solidarity among its member states. The organization operates in the Western Hemisphere, and has its headquarters in Washington, D.C., United States. The organization's stated goal is to promote democracy, human rights, and social and economic development in the Americas. The OAS was established as a response to the growing tensions between the United States and its Latin American neighbors, particularly in the aftermath of World War II. The organization's founding members included the United States, Canada, and 20 Latin American nations. Today, the OAS has 35 member states, including all countries in the Americas except Cuba. The OAS operates through a number of different bodies and programs, including the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, and the Inter-American Development Bank. The organization also sponsors a number of cultural initiatives, such as the Inter-American Culture and Sports Festival, and the Inter-American Children's Institute. The OAS has been involved in a number of controversial issues over the years, including the 2009 Honduran coup d'état, the 2019 Venezuelan presidential crisis, and the ongoing migrant crisis in the Americas. Despite these controversies, the OAS remains an important forum for regional cooperation and dialogue in the Americas.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Organization of American States (OAS) has played a significant role in the relationship between Cuba and the United States. Cuba was suspended from the OAS in 1962 after the Cuban Revolution, and its readmission has been a contentious issue in recent years. The OAS has been involved in efforts to promote democracy and human rights in Cuba, and has criticized the country's record on these issues.

Washington.passage: D.C. Washington, D.C., formally the District of Columbia and commonly referred to as Washington or D.C., is the capital of the United States. Founded after the American Revolution as the new national capital, Washington was named after George Washington, first President of the United States and Founding Father. As the seat of government and administrative center of the U.S., Washington is home to many national landmarks, museums, and monuments. These include the White House, the Capitol, the Supreme Court, the National Mall, and the Smithsonian museums. The city is also known for its vibrant cultural scene, including the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the National Symphony Orchestra, and numerous art galleries and theaters. the Inter-American Commission on Human R.passage: Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) is a regional intergovernmental organization founded in 1959 under the auspices of the Organization of American States (OAS). The IACHR is composed of representatives from the member states of the OAS, and it is headquartered in Washington, D.C. The IACHR has the mandate to promote and protect human rights in the Americas. It does so by investigating alleged human rights violations, providing advice to member states, and working with civil society organizations. The Commission also serves as a forum for dialogue on human rights issues, and it engages in advocacy and awareness-raising activities. The IACHR has a broad mandate that encompasses a range of human rights, including civil and political rights, economic and social rights, and cultural rights. It also has specific mandates related to the rights of women, children, indigenous peoples, and Afro-descendants. The IACHR operates through a number of mechanisms, including individual petitions, inter-state petitions, and on-site visits. It also has a number of specialized units, including the Unit on the Rights of Women, the Unit on the Rights of Children, and the Unit on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. The IACHR is widely regarded as a key player in the promotion and protection of human rights in the Americas. Its work has helped to raise awareness of human rights issues, and it has contributed to the development of human rights norms and standards in the region.

Kyrgyzstan.passage: Kyrgyzstan is a country located in Central Asia. It is a landlocked country with a total area of 199,900 square kilometers. Kyrgyzstan is bordered by Kazakhstan to the north, Uzbekistan to the west, Tajikistan to the southwest, and China to the east. Its capital and largest city is Bishkek. Kyrgyzstan is a parliamentary republic with a president as the head of state and a prime minister as the head of government. The country has a population of around 6 million people, with Kyrgyz making up the largest ethnic group, followed by Uzbeks, Russians, and Ukrainians. The country's economy is based largely on agriculture, with livestock farming and sheep and goat herding being the most important activities. Kyrgyzstan is also rich in natural resources, including gold, coal, and hydropower. Kyrgyzstan is known for its beautiful landscapes, including the Tien Shan mountains, which are home to many rare plant and animal species. The country is also home to several important cultural sites, such as the Burana Tower, a 9th-century minaret, and the Issyk Kul Lake, the largest lake in Kyrgyzstan and one of the largest mountain lakes in the world.

SCO.passage: SCO Group, Inc. was a software company headquartered in Lindon, Utah, that developed and sold computer software, with a focus on the Unix operating system. The company was formed in 1979 as a joint venture between AT&T and IBM, and was later acquired by Caldera International in 2001. In 2003, SCO Group filed a lawsuit against IBM, alleging that IBM had contributed code to the Linux operating system that infringed on SCO's intellectual property rights. The lawsuit sparked controversy in the software industry and was widely criticized by the open-source community. In 2010, SCO Group filed for bankruptcy and was later acquired by a group of investors.
